description: This survey helps us understand your skills, availability, and working style to pair you with a compatible teammate.

questions.question: Rate your comfort level with Python programming.
Rate your experience with data manipulation libraries (pandas, NumPy).
Rate your comfort with statistical analysis and hypothesis testing.
Rate your experience with data visualization (matplotlib, seaborn, Tableau).
Rate your familiarity with machine learning concepts and tools.
Rate your experience working with healthcare or biomedical datasets.
Rate your comfort with SQL or database querying.
What technical skill do you most want to improve this semester?
What is a technical strength you could teach a teammate?
How many hours per week do you realistically plan to dedicate to this course outside of class?
How would you describe your typical approach to deadlines?
options: I prefer to finish well ahead of time
I work steadily and finish on time
I tend to work best closer to the deadline

questions.question: What grade outcome are you aiming for in this course?
options: B (solid performance, balanced with other commitments)
Pass (completing requirements is my main goal)

questions.question: Which time blocks are you typically available for team meetings?
Do you have any major commitments this semester that might affect your availability?
I am comfortable giving constructive feedback to teammates.
I am comfortable receiving critical feedback on my work.
I prefer frequent check-ins with teammates rather than working independently until deadlines.
I am comfortable speaking up when I disagree with a teammate's approach.
When facing a disagreement in a team, I usually:
options: Defer to others to avoid conflict
Seek outside input to resolve it

questions.question: How do you prefer to communicate with teammates?
Describe a positive team experience you have had. What made it work?
Describe a frustrating team experience. What went wrong?
When starting a new data problem, I tend to:
options: Dive into the data and explore first
Plan my approach carefully before touching the data
Look for similar examples or tutorials to guide me

questions.question: What is your primary academic or professional background?
When interpreting results, I am more drawn to:
What is a biomedical or healthcare problem you would be excited to explore with data?
